text:
DONNA NOVITSKY: Hello,
everybody out there. We are so excited to
chat with you today. Just a real quick intro.
And then we'll dig in. My name is Donna Novitsky. I am an entrepreneur, CEO, CMO.

But I started my career
as a product manager at Sun Microsystems. And that's basically the
foundation for everything.

I've been working in
startup companies. I've been a partner in
a venture capital firm.

I'm also on a couple of boards. And I've been teaching here at
Stanford for almost 20 years now.

LAURA MARINO: And
I am Laura Marino. I have been leading products
across different sized companies

in different industries
for over 20 or 25 years. I'm currently a general manager
and VP of product at Nubank.

That's the largest fintech
company in Latin America. But as I said, I've been chief
product officer and product

leader in companies
across industries, from speech recognition to
legal technology, fintech.

I'm also a board member. And I have been an instructor
at Stanford for many years

now as well. And we're just thrilled
to be here and share a little bit of the experience
that we've accumulated together

jointly for over 50 years. So with that, I wanted to
start with the realization, how

you approach strategy,
the challenges that you face as a product leader. And we know that most
of you joining us

are either current product
leaders or aspiring product leaders. So your strategy will really
depend on the type of product.

Is it a business to consumer,
business to business? Is it a marketplace? Is it a platform?

It will depend on
the type of industry. Are you in a highly
regulated industry--

fintech, healthtech? And it also will depend on the
maturity stage of the company.

Today, we're going to
focus on that last point and how you need to be
thinking about your strategy

as you go through the
various stages of maturity in the company. So let's talk first about
those stages of maturity.

Companies typically go
through three stages-- an early stage, the
early startup stage,

where the company is trying
to get to product market fit, finding a product that
serves a need in the market.

And what you have is a team
that's doing all kinds of things just to get something
out and test it and prove

that it has value. After that, after you've
gotten to product market fit, you get into the scale-up stage.

And this is a very
different stage. This is all about scaling,
being able to prove that once

you got product market
fit, that you now can really grow within that
segment that wants your product.

And then you get to
mature companies. Mature companies are
typically companies

that might already have
gotten through a liquidity event, an IPO, a big merger.

And these are companies
that are operating with an understood
business model.

And they have more of
a cadence of operation. And their challenge
is how to continue

to grow that big company while
also maintaining innovation. So with that, what we're
going to focus on today

is Donna is going
to talk first about, what are the mistakes
that you need to avoid when breathing
life into your first product

in that early stage and how to
accelerate this time to volume

during that early stage
and avoiding mistakes of big company thought process?

Then I'll talk about that
scale-up stage and what are the transitions
that companies

that are past that early stage
need to make in order to succeed when they are in scale-up.

And we'll talk very specifically
about the challenges as product leaders during
that high-growth stage.

And then Donna will come back
and talk about the mature stage and specifically how to
align product strategy

with the company strategy
when you're already in a mature company. So with that, Donna,
I'm handing it to you.

DONNA NOVITSKY: All right. So yeah, as Laura
said, the early stage

is characterized by a number
of different things, what we're describing here. And this is where I've spent the
majority of my career wearing

many hats. Sometimes, your
CEO, maybe your CFO, may be doing a lot
of the product work.

You're also at a
stage where you have to conserve cash because
you probably don't even your revenue model yet.

You have some
hypotheses about it. But you are in process
of proving all that.

We're going to
talk about what it takes to get those
first early adopter customers in a market that
may or may not even exist.

You're trying to figure out
what's your MVP, your Minimum Viable Product,
how quickly can you

get that to market and into
the hands of paying customers. Usually, this is
all do it yourself.

No partners yet in play. And the competition may not
even be fully clear yet.

So that's what we're
defining as the early stage. That's the earliest
of early stage.

And in this stage, you find that
your product strategy basically

equals your company strategy. If you're trying to do
more than one thing, if you're trying to
have multiple product

lines at the same
time at launch, you're trying to do too much. This is in a stage where
you need to be super focused

on getting those early
products to market and acquiring your
first customers.

So we're going to talk
about how you do that. What I like to
say is the product

and the market
development processes are strategic and iterative. And they have to be
done simultaneously.

That might be obvious. But what we find is a lot of
people in early-stage customers,

product leaders who are bringing
first early products to market may be thinking all
about the product

and not thinking about
the market sufficiently. So we like to say it
takes two to tango.

So one person needs to be
thinking about, follow my lead. I'm building the product.

Your co-founders and partners
in early stage ventures are going to be
saying, follow my lead.

I'm finding the
customers and the market. They are both correct. You need to be
working together to do
both of these at the same time. But it's really hard. Building a new market is hard.

I'm sure some of you
have tried to do this, gotten started doing this. But you realized,
wow, this is not

like working in
the big companies. We don't have customers. We don't have a product yet. We don't have budget yet.

We maybe haven't even
raised any type of funding and are bootstrapping this.

It's not clear that people
understand the problem that we're solving. And nobody knows who we are.

So I like to think of
this with some parallels to a movie called Field of
Dreams, where in that movie,

the statement is, if we
build it, they will come. And that only works
in the movies.

I'm here to tell you. That does not work in real life. It does not work when you're
bringing new products to market.

You have to be building
the market at the same time as the product. You can't just build it
and throw it out there

and expect people to buy it. So how do you do this
difficult challenge?

You have to use what
you have in order to get what you don't have yet. And what you have is
a team of superstars.

There's yourself
and your early stage partners that are getting
this business going.

You have a game-changing
product coming to life. And in that, you
have prototypes.

You have PowerPoint slides. You have demos. And those things are all going
to help you get to market.

And never underestimate
the power of your vision. You have a strong, compelling
vision of where you're going,

why the world needs
what you're doing. And that's exciting. That's exciting to customers.

It's exciting to
yourself and your team. And the more you can convey that
excitement, the more successful

you're going to be in getting
your company off the ground. So a question for you is,
what do customers care about?

And a lot of product
leaders, I know, like you all must
be thinking about, what is it that you think
customers care about?
Well, they care about price. They care about functionality. They care about quality.

They care about, does this
product solve the problem or realize the
opportunity that I have?

Those are usually the answers
I get when I ask this question. But there is a much
simpler answer.

The simpler answer is that
customers care about themselves. And so if you get
out of your own heads

and put yourself into the
head of your customers, you realize that those customers
or those prospective customers,

they're thinking about, how
do I look good to my boss? How do I look good
to my friends?

How is this product
going to affect my life? They're not thinking about
what are the features

and functions of the product. So this changes the whole game
for early-stage customers.

It means that what
you need to do with these early-stage
customer partners

is establish a basis of trust. Early stage, bringing
new companies to market,

is all about
relationship building. And the way that you
build relationships

with your initial
early stage customers is that you demonstrate
that you comprehend

their problem or
the opportunity, that you are competent and
you have the skills to solve

this problem, and that
you genuinely care about their success.

If you establish
those three things, then you will be
establishing trust

with your potential
customers, which is what allows them to take the
leap to buy a product that's

brand new coming to market. So you need to put yourself
in your customer's shoes

in order to do this or
potential customers. And so what we're going
to do in order to do that

is leverage what we have
to get what we need. So we're going to market the
company, not just the product

because the product, by
definition, does not fully exist yet. This is an exploration period.

So you need to cast a wide net. You need to be talking to a
number of different market

segments, different levels
of people in organizations. And you need to be
asking a lot of question,

taking a lot of notes,
listening to their answers, and really exploring and
understanding the market.

To do this, we're
going to use something that I call the player. The player is what
you are marketing

in lieu of having a product. And so we're going to
talk some more about that in a couple of slides.

Then once you decide where the
strategic market opportunities are, you're going to lock
your customers in step by step

with your development process. Choose them wisely. And invest heavily in those bets
to make sure that they become

great reference customers. So I call this the tango. On the left side here, you see
a fairly simplified product

development cycle. You start out with some
ideas on a whiteboard. You go to debugging and
beta testing that product.

You eventually have a
production-ready product. That product goes live.

And you roll it out globally. Most product managers
and product leaders are very familiar with this.

What they haven't
necessarily thought about is the market
development cycle, which

moves in tandem with the
product development cycle. So while you're having your
whiteboard discussions,

you're having exploratory
customer meetings. While you're doing your
debugging and beta,

you're having your
product feedback sessions with customers and
building credibility. From there, you get
to paying customers.

And you do need
customers to have spent money on your
products initially,

not just testing it to
do you a favor for free because customers
who haven't paid

do not become great references. And you need great references
in order to establish a market.

So this is fairly intuitive
and obvious when you see it all laid out like this.

So we'll talk about a couple of
common mistakes that are made.

And I have been in-- depending
on how you count them, my current company is my
third or my 19th startup.

So I have had opportunities to
make all these mistakes and more in all those
different companies.

So one of the ones
that we see most often is starting to sell too late.

And the other one is
overemphasis on the product. So we're going to
drill down on those.

The mistake in starting too
late is product managers say, great, I've got my funding
or I'm bootstrapping this.

Let's go build the vision. Let's go build this amazing,
wonderful idea that we have.

What's wrong with that is
they build too much stuff. They build the wrong stuff.

And as a consequence of
that, they deliver too late. So what you're trying
to do in early stage

is identify your Minimum
Viable Product or MVP, which I'm sure many of
you have heard about.

But that's not sufficient. That is necessary
but not sufficient. You need to also learn
how to sell and seek out

your early customer partners who
are going to eventually become your initial
reference customers.

So to do that, I
recommend that you meet with at least 30
prospective customers

over a time period
of three months. And these are some of the
questions that you want to ask.

Notice that the questions really
cover two different domains. One is about the functionality
of the product, which

is, where is your pain? What are you doing
to address it now? What are your competitors
offering and promising?

And then the other domain is,
how do decisions get made? It could be an individual
deciding to download your app.

Or it could be an enterprise
deciding to allocate budget to purchase your product.

So how are they organized? How are they making
those decisions?

Who has the budget? And one of the biggest questions
is, what are their priorities?

My favorite question
overall to ask while doing this market research
is, tell me all the reasons you

would not buy this product. Because in the end, that's the
thing you really want to know.

So the second big area
is how to accelerate time to volume by avoiding the
big company thought process.

So I started out my career
as a product manager at Sun Microsystems. In a period of three years,
I launched 19 different data

communication products. So I went through this over
and over and over again.

And our approach at
Sun back in the day was a very tactical process.

As a product manager,
we identified customers who would
do us the favor of testing our new products
before they came out.

They would identify features,
quality issues, et cetera.

We with engineering
would decide, are we going to
make these changes? Are we going to fix these bugs?

Or can we get this
to market as is? The company in
parallel was learning how to deliver it,
how to sell it,

how to support it, how to market
it, all the rest of the things that go around bringing
products to market.

The customers who were our
early partners testing,

they may buy the product. But they may not. Honestly, we weren't
focusing on that at all.

The product was
finalized and launched. So the problem is
in early stage,

that big company
process is doing insufficient strategic
customer and market

qualification up front. And we were not focused
on referenceability. What you have to get
right in startups

is choose your first
customers in the right market. And 80% of them need to actually
pay money for the product--

maybe not the full amount,
but at least something. The reason is this early
product testing is strategic.

Because when you're
in a big company, that company already has
a market, a reputation, and existing customer
relationships.

But startups do not. So your first partners
in testing your product
are going to be the true judge. Do they buy it? Do they use it?

Do they recommend
it to their friends? And are they in the right
market segment to begin with?

It's going to be a big
opportunity for you. And if they are not,
you're back to ground zero

in market development. And the tango would look
something like this. You're in a market
that's too small.

Or maybe you don't
even get there. So what you need to do is avoid
choosing the wrong customers

in your beta testing cycles. A wrong customer is a
customer in the wrong market.

It's not large with
repeatable sales. Their priorities
are not mainstream. You're going to end up
allocating scarce engineering

resources to unique
development that doesn't scale. And your customer
has no intention

of buying when the
testing is complete, which is an
opportunity cost to you because they're not going
to be a reference for you.

Bottom line is a customer
who is not referenceable. Those customers will establish
your market, your reputation,

whether you like it or not. So your three goals are
feedback to product development,

selecting your
strategic customers, and establishing a base of
diehard, loyal customers.

Those are the goals of
early-stage product testing.

And so life changes when
you move to scale up. And Laura is going
to talk about that.

LAURA MARINO: Yes. So when you move from that
early stage to scale-up, essentially you're transitioning
to a stage of very rapid growth.

And things are very different. And just so that you're aware,
for those companies that

successfully end
the early stage, 60% die in the scale-up stage.

And this is from some analysts
here in Silicon Valley

that have done the analysis. And the reason is
that scaling up

is a very different ballgame
than being in the early stage and trying to find this product
market fit for the first time.

So to succeed, once the company
is past that first early stage,

startups really need
to embrace changes. And the first question is,
why do they need to change?

Why is a transition
needed in the first place? Well, to explain that,
what we want to look at

is, what is the strategy? How do you operate
in the early stage? In the early stage--

and some of this was
covered by Donna-- you're really needing to
move fast and iterate. You don't yet have
product market fit.

You need to be
figuring out how you build this market, how you build
the product for that market.

You have a team that's doing
whatever it takes in order to get the successful
product out

in order to secure those
unique customers who are going to be your partners. Communication in the
company is very informal.

It's a small team. Everybody sort of knows
what you're going after. And there's knowledge that
is distributed very easily.

Even the most sophisticated CEO
will be sitting with their team

and sharing a lot
of the knowledge. The engineer who
started the product will be sharing the knowledge.

And that is great. But the problem is that
once you start growing, once the company grows to
hundreds or more employees

and you go to hundreds or
thousands of customers, that doesn't scale.

And what you get is total chaos. So this is why companies, when
they get into this high-growth

stage, need to make several
transitions in order to succeed. And there are actually five
key transitions that companies

need to go through. One is moving from having
this group of people who know everything to embedding
that knowledge in processes.

The other thing is moving
from relationships-- maybe the CEO was the one
selling every customer--

to building a brand that's
recognized in the market-- moving from the
early product that

got to product market fit
to a scalable product, then moving from
owning everything

to leveraging
partnerships, and finally moving from being very
opportunistic to starting

to think very strategically
about how you're going to scale. All of those five transitions
require that the product leaders

be very directly involved. But because we don't
have time today to go through all
of those, I'm just

going to focus on talking about
transitioning from early product to scalable product.

And notice that I'm not
talking about transitioning from MVP to a scalable product.

Because for you to have
entered the high-growth stage,

you're way past MVP. You now have a
product that actually has proven to be successful
in a segment of the market.

And now, what you
really need to do is grow that as fast as you can. So what are the challenges
that you as a product leader

are going to be
facing when you're moving from this early
product to a scalable product?

And to understand
that, let's go back to think, how do you
develop product when

you're in that early stage? Again, you have to
move fast and iterate.

You don't know what's
going to stick. You don't know yet what is going
to be important for your target customers.

So testing and iterating
is absolutely critical. And the goal is to build
features and functionality

that's visible to
those target customers. There is no time to be thinking
about scalable architecture

or about tools for
implementation because, really, what you want is to
have your engineering team

be producing as much
functionality as quickly as possible. And in fact, engineers
are even rewarded

for coming up with shortcuts--
how quickly can they get something out so that you
can show it to your customers.

And then you have to
do whatever it takes to secure those early adopters.

Donna talked about
how critical it is to have those
initial customers who are going to be
your references, who

are going to be your partners
in building the product. So you are going to be willing
to do unique things to secure

those adopters. So if your product
were a building,

by the end of this
early stage, you're building would probably
look something like this.

It would have a bunch
of things that you built for specific customers.

And even if you built
them in a way that could be used by
others, you probably know that only one
or two customers

are ever going to use it. But you are willing
to do that because you had to secure those customers.

And then your
building will likely have a whole bunch of areas
that were built very poorly.

Those were the
shortcuts and hacks that engineering was
actually encouraged

to do so that you could
get something out quickly. And your foundation
is probably going

to be very shaky
because, again, there was no time or focus
on building something

that would scale to a
large number of customers. This is what we typically
think of as technical debt.

Now, these are problems
that exist or start in that early stage.

But the problem is that
as you start scaling, if you don't pay attention and
start addressing those things,

you are going to be
in a lot of hurt. So let's first start talking
about customer-specific

functionality and
how you handle that. Now, customer-specific
functionality is primarily a problem
if you're in B2B.

But even if you're
in B2C and you have been kind of now hanging
on to these initial customers

that you had and
they are dictating what you should do
next, you will be having the same types of problems.

So what is the cost of
customer-specific functionality?

Again, during the early
stage, those early customers are absolutely critical.

You do need to secure them. And it is OK for you
as the product leader to accept to do stuff
for them that you know

may not be important for
the rest of the market. That's OK. You need to do that
in the early stage.

However, if you don't change and
you don't change that behavior

and you start growing,
what's going to happen is those early customers
will take over your roadmap.

And the list of things that
they will want you to do will start being
so long that you

are going to be at risk
of missing building what the market actually is.

So you need to start
reining in those very powerful early customers.

And that is not easy. But I have a couple of
tips that have worked well

for me in various companies. The first thing is make sure
that you are communicating

proactively to those customers
what you're building and why.

If you don't, those
customers will assume that your roadmap is
this blank sheet of paper

waiting for them to
tell you what to do. But if you go proactively
and share with them,

this is what we're seeing, these
are the trends we're seeing, and this is why we're
focusing, at a minimum,

they will get the message
that your roadmap is not dictated just by them.

The second tip-- and this
one actually worked really well-- is leverage
customer councils.

One of the companies where
I was a product leader, we sold software for
the legal industry.

And our main customers-- our
target customers were the 1,000 largest law firms in the US,
UK, Canada, and Australia.

And as you can imagine, those
large law firms, each of one thought that they were the most
important customer that we had.

And each of one wanted to
dictate what we wanted. So what we found
very helpful was

we would bring them
in groups together. And within law firms,
they have a hierarchy.

So we could identify which ones
considered themselves peers. And we would bring
group of peers together.

We would ask them what were the
trends that they were seeing. We would share with
them what we were doing.

And then we would let
them talk to each other. And what was very
interesting was

to see a customer that had been
pounding their fist saying, you have to build this,
you have to build, this is very important, realize
that none of their peers

cared about that. So that actually
also helped them realize that we
were not building

a product for any one
of them individually. We were building a
product to serve them

as the leaders in
the legal industry.

But even with those
strategies, sometimes you just need to be prepared to say no.

And what it means to
be prepared to say no is you need to be very
clear about the trade-offs

that you would
need to do in order to accommodate a unique
requirement of one

of those customers. And you need to make sure that
you communicate that to your CEO

because you can be sure that
those big initial customers have a direct line to the CEO.

And if you say no to
them, they probably are going to go
straight to the CEO. So you need to be incredibly
clear with your CEO

and your executives
what are the trade-offs. If we say yes to this
customer that has been

a very important customer and-- these are all the things that
are not going to get done.

These are all the things
that we had promised to sales that are not going to get done. And when you're very
clear, it's a lot easier

for your executive
team to be supportive. And it may be even easier
to convince the customer.

Now, there are extreme cases-- and I had to deal with that-- eventually, you may
need to fire a customer

if that customer is actually
forcing you to do something. Hopefully, you don't
need to get into that.

And at some point,
I'll share that story. I've shared it before. But again, if you are
not able to say no,

the cost is that you
will be diverting your unique
engineering resources

to build something
that's not going to serve the market you're going after. And that is not going
to allow you to scale.

So let's talk about the
next one, technical debt. Every startup has
technical debt when

they exit their initial stage. Because if they had
tried to build everything

totally scalable
and with the highest quality from the very
beginning, they probably

would have run out
of money before they got their first product out. So it's absolutely
natural that there

would be technical debt when
you start to scale-up stage.

But you need to realize that now
that you're in scale-up mode, you need to start addressing
that because technical debt

in its, let's say, less
dangerous form will

start slowing you down. Building stuff on top of
poorly written code gets hard.

So your engineering
team is going to start slowing down, trying to
do more things on top of stuff that was not good quality.

But in its more pernicious
mode, technical debt will start appearing in
front of the customers.

Things start crashing. Things don't scale. Latency of the
website gets poor.

So that's when it gets very
dangerous because your customers will start noticing it. So how to address it-- and
what I call it is face reality.

The first thing you
need to understand is that the way that the
engineering team was allocated

in the early stage is not the
same way in which it can be allocated in the later stage.

In the early stage, when you're
just starting with the product, most of the bandwidth
of engineering

is going to build
new functionality. And there's a little
bit that is going to go to maintenance and
implementation support.

If you're building B2B
software, the software, when you sell it to
a customer, needs

to be implemented so that
it ties into the business processes and the other
systems that the customer has.

And typically, engineering
in the early stage will get involved in that.

But what happens is
that if you believe that that type of
allocation can continue,

the reality is as you
start adding new customers and you start adding
more functionality,

you now need more engineering
bandwidth for maintenance because there are more
pieces of functionality

to maintain and evolve. There's no one feature
that's done in version 1. When you launch
new functionality,

you're going to have
to iterate on it. You are now going to have
this technical debt that

starts going to be showing up. And the latency may
start increasing

if you now have a large volume
of customers doing transactions. The escalations will increase.

If things start breaking
up now, engineering is going to have to dedicate
more time to address bugs.

And if you have a
complex B2B software, you're going to have to
have your engineering team

start building those tools
that would allow somebody else, like a professional
services team,

to do the implementations. And I do have a story. When I joined one
of my companies

that was in the talent
acquisition space, I knew that they had let the
previous VP of product go.

And when I started to understand
what had been the issues, what I was told is that
the VP of product

kept promising things
but never delivering. And as I started drilling
deeper, what I found

was that product and
engineering were still operating with the mindset
that they were living

in the left side of the screen. And they would promise-- they promised they were going to
deliver all this functionality.

But the reality is that by
then, the company had already secured a lot of
customers, some very big.

And what was happening
was engineering was being pulled
into fixing things,

into implementing and
launching those new customers because they were the only ones
who could go into the database

and set it up for
the new customer. So the reality is
that they did not have the bandwidth to deliver
all the functionality that they

were promising. But they had not realized that. So it's really important for
you as the product leader to see

that you need to transition. And unless you get a lot
of additional engineers, you need to start
setting the expectations

with sales and with
your executive team that you're not going to be
delivering new functionality

at the same rate
as you were before and that instead, you are going
to have to be dedicating some

of your precious
resources in engineering to maintenance and to
paying technical debt

and to making the
architecture scalable. So how do you do that?

The tips for doing
that-- the first thing is partner closely with
engineering to really understand

which ones are the
areas of the product and the code that need
attention most urgently.

Now, engineering will
probably tell you they want to
re-architect everything. They will want to stop sales
for six months, no new features.

They just want to
re-architect everything. And of course,
that's not possible.

But you can partner with them
to really get them to tell you, like, if we double the
number of customers,

what's going to break first? Which ones are the
areas of the code that engineers always
afraid of touching

and they don't want to evolve
because it's so complex and it's a really poor code?

Once you understand which
ones are those priority areas, then what you need to
do is prioritize work

on that as part of your roadmap. I have seen companies
where there's

this belief that engineering
has their own roadmap. And then there's
a product roadmap. It should never be that case.

Engineering is one group. And you as the product
leader should really know where they are
dedicating their time.

But you also need to be
the one saying explicitly that you are dedicating
part of that bandwidth

to improving the architecture,
to paying technical debt. And it's your responsibility
to sell that to your executives

and to the sales team. You have to be the one
explaining to them why this is a good investment
because customers

expect performance. Customers expect security. So it should not be engineering
having to explain to sales why

this is important. You should be the one
explaining it to them and making them realize
that this is actually

going to help the customers. And finally,
communicate proactively.

Again, if you're not telling
your leadership, your sales

team, your marketing team
why you are putting engineers in that priority, they will
be complaining that you're not

delivering as much as before. So really explaining why this
is important is very critical.

So those were the key things
that I wanted to highlight. Again, there's a lot
more things that you

need to be thinking
about when you're transitioning from early
stage to the scale-up stage.

But we'll leave those
for the next opportunity. And with that, Donna.
DONNA NOVITSKY: Back to me. Thank you, Laura. That was amazing. I love the house. That's my favorite part.

So thank you for that. Now, we're going to move
on to the mature stage.

And this section,
we're going to talk about defining the
characteristics

of a mature company
here on this slide. So my earlier slide, we
talked about the team

wearing many hats. At this stage, you
have your specialized. You have experts.

Most of the functional bases
are covered, if not all of them. And so it's a very
different ballgame

than when you're in
early-stage mode. The company's been
selling for a while.

You have budgets. You have plans. You have cash, whereas
in startups and even

early-stage companies can
be very cash-constrained. You have customers already. You have a reputation
in the market.

And now, you're probably looking
to expand to new geographies. You're probably past the
IPO stage or the M&A stage.

You may be actually
looking to be the one acquiring new companies
at this stage,

bringing in new product lines,
expanding your partnerships so that you can grow faster.

And the competition in general
is very well understood. And you know how you're
differentiating yourself.

So the big challenge
here is, how do we maintain our market
leadership and continue

innovating with a
very mature market and without kind of
killing what's driving

all the revenue in the company? So first of all, unlike
our early-stage company,

product strategy does not
equal company strategy. In fact, product
strategy is just a part

of a much bigger strategy. In fact, your company strategy
may not even be the whole thing.

There may be a corporate
strategy above that that's dealing with things like
diversification, M&A, questions

that might be one or two levels
above product leadership level folks.

So you are part of a
much bigger picture. What's critical at this stage
is that your product strategy

aligns with your
company strategy. So let's talk about
what that means.

So there are really
three things to consider about your overall
company strategy.

One is, what is your
competitive domain? So your domain is your target
market and the existing

competitors in that market. So for example, you might be
in the retail banking space.

You might be in luxury
automotive space. You might be in the
smartphone business.

That is your competitive domain. It's an area that has--
it's an existing market.

It's well defined. There are many competitors
in general in that market. So given that, part 2, what
is your competitive advantage?

Think of your competitive
advantage as your superpowers. What is it that your
company is really good at?

It could be that you have
amazing brand loyalty. It could be that you have
amazing supplier relationships.

Or it could be that
you have incredible IP. Those are examples of superpower
competitive advantages.

And you as a product
leader should be very familiar with what those are. Third, it is said that a
vision without execution

is just a hallucination. So that brings us to the
third leg of this stool,

your execution capabilities. So as a company, what
are you really good at?

Is it that you have an
incredible sales organization, you're able to bring
new products in quickly,

and sell them to
existing customers? That's the way that
Cisco expanded so fast in the '90s and became the
market leader in networking

equipment. It could be supplier
relationships. It could be customer
data management.

Think about what is
your company uniquely capable at executing on.

And then you need to make sure
that your product strategy is consistent with
these three things.

So we like to lay
it out like this. On the top, you see
the company strategy, which is built on
what we just talked

about-- your competitive
advantages and your execution capabilities. But under that, there's a whole
other series of strategies.

You've got marketing strategy,
operations, product, finance, HR, a whole bunch more of them.

So the question is, what are
you really good at in marketing? So in marketing, you
may be really good

at things like promotions
or distribution strategy.

What exists in the company? And how can you as
a product leader leverage those
assets in marketing?

In operations, you
may have a superpower in terms of your ability
to do high quality

manufacturing or fast turn
manufacturing or responsive

manufacturing. So what is it there in
operations that your company is

particularly good at? And that brings us
to product strategy. There are a number of different
types of product strategies

that you can think about. So to give you some
examples of those, one is you could have a
product strategy that's

centered on innovation and
continuous improvement. This is common for companies
in the tech space, something

like Apple or Samsung, focused
on continually innovating

and bringing out new products. You could have a
product strategy based on market leadership
and defense, which

would be something like
LVMH, where they've been market leaders forever.

And they want to maintain
that leadership position. You could also have
a product strategy

around efficiency
and optimization, where you're
optimizing processes

for efficiency and cost. Think Amazon, Walmart,
companies that

are able to just efficiently
roll new things out into a huge operation base.

You could have a strategy
around diversification. In this case, think
about Coca-Cola,

where they started
out with Coca-Cola. Then they brought in Diet Coke. And then they brought
in health drinks.

And they brought
in energy drinks. And they brought in waters and
all different diversified drinks

but all in the area
that they started in. And finally, another
one is sustainability

and long-term planning. So if you look at--
an example of this would be the auto industry,
where auto companies are now

developing EVs, Electronic
Vehicles, because they can see the writing on the wall
that at some point in the future

they are going to need to
evolve to new technologies, new platforms in order
to sustain their growth.

So those are some examples
of different types of product

strategy that you can consider. Your company may have
other areas or combinations

of those areas. So then we go back to our
hierarchy of our company's

overall assets. And we take our
product strategy here that we've just identified
and saying, now,

are we aligning with
the rest of the company? For example, say we are a
fashion company, a high end

fashion company, like
LVMH or Gucci or Hermes. That company has
certain capabilities

and certain
competitive advantages. Their marketing
strategy is reaching out

to high-end customers and
maintaining that customer loyalty.

Their operations strategy is all
about premium product, premium content and rolling out
for their customers.

And that aligns with
their product strategy. If you were the product
leader at LVMH or Gucci

and you decide you want
to bring out something like quick turn, fast
fashion, like, for example,

Zara or one of the
quick fashion providers,

you're not going
to see alignment with the existing marketing
strategy or operations

strategy in the company. So those are the
things that you need to be thinking about even as
you're considering evolving

and working with your
counterparts in marketing, operations, and the
rest of the company.

So if you do this
right, you will end up with alignment of
strategy at every level--

your product with your company
capabilities and ability to execute. And you will look like
a high performance

Formula 1 racing team. And when that car pulls
into the pit crew,

that crew is a
well-oiled machine. Everybody knows exactly
what they should be doing.

They know when to do their part. They know when to get out of
the way of their colleagues.

And product strategy is a
key piece of that execution.

So that's just a little
taste of some of our ideas and our content for early-stage,
scale-up stage, mature stage.

We wanted to
summarize and give you a few minutes for Q&A. Love
to hear your questions.

So what we talked about
in the early stage was some mistakes to avoid. When you're breathing life
into your first products,

make sure that you're building
your market while you're building your product. It takes two to tango.

Second, we talked
about accelerating time to volume by avoiding big
company thought processes

in your early testing cycles. Make sure that those
early testing customers

will buy and be great
reference customers for you so that you can get more
customers like them.

Third, Laura talked about
some of the transitions. Startups must embrace to
scale and that early stage

strategies just don't scale. So you have to be
thinking about that.

And she gave you a lot
of great tips for how to make those transitions.

And some of the product
challenges to scaling, about how to rein in
those early customers,

and address your technical debt. And finally, we talked
about mature companies

and how they need to
align product strategy with their company
strategy and make sure that that is consistent with
the operations and execution

capabilities of the
overall organization. And so with that, at
the end of the day--

this is just a note of
inspiration for all the product managers, product
leaders, aspiring product

leaders out there. At the end of the day,
your job isn't just to get the requirements right.

Your job is to change the world. And it takes a lot
of coordination

among a lot of people
within your company, outside of your company. And we're super excited
to be able to offer

our insights from many, many
years as product leaders. And now I'm happy to
take some questions.

MODERATOR: Awesome. Thanks so much, Laura and Donna. So as a reminder, so
there's the Q&A box.

Please feel free to
submit your questions. And just because I've
been seeing this a lot, that, yes, this

how has the rise
of generative AI going to affect the

mature companies,

especially in the tech industry? DONNA NOVITSKY: I'll
take a stab at that.

And, Laura, you can add to that. It's going to
become fundamental. So we already see
that generative AI

is having an effect on
pretty much every aspect of every company. Just like we talked
about, there's

generative AI in marketing, in

Laura, do you have
some other thoughts? LAURA MARINO: Yeah, I would
say every company right now is looking at how to

And the question is really,

And companies need
to look at that. When you're thinking
about your product, I think that the main
point is, what can you

provide to your customers
that's fundamentally different because you're leveraging AI?

There are some cases
where AI may not make a big difference in

and look at, what's
the value that you want to provide to your customer?

And how do you think
AI can actually allow you to do a much

different job than what
is available today? MODERATOR: Great. Thanks so much.

OK, next question
from [INAUDIBLE]. So when working as a product
manager in a consultancy company

or a product manager
for an internal product, it seems similar to an
early-age startup but not 100%.

Do you have any
suggestions or tips on product strategy
in these contexts?

DONNA NOVITSKY: I did a lot
of work with startup companies when I was in the venture
world, where the my role was,

basically, here's $3 million. And Donna, she'll
help you get started and help them with their
initial product strategy

and go-to market strategy. And what was really
important there is to really figure out
where are we going to focus.

To be successful as an
early-stage company or a bigger company that's bringing
something new to life,

you really need to know
exactly who you're selling to and what it that is
critical for them

to achieve the, as
Geoffrey Moore would say, compelling reason to buy,
to achieve the results

that they're looking for. So what I found as a consultant
is we put a lot of work

into identifying that. But then we also
put a lot of work into making sure that everybody
was involved in those decisions

and that as it was
handed off to-- for me, it was usually my
replacement in the company

as I moved on to the
next thing, making sure that person was, to the extent
possible, a part of that process

so they could continue
running with the ball. So that would be my
two cents on that.

LAURA MARINO: So I don't know
if I interpreted the question slightly differently. But if you are a product person
in charge of internal products,

your target customers
are the rest of the employees in a company.

And that can be challenging
because you may not be treated the same way.

But I would say, for
internal products, you need to go through
the same process. Just really understand what
you're trying to solve for.

Really talk to all of
those internal customers you're going to have. On the consulting
side-- and that

one is probably the one that
I wasn't completely clear what it was. But what I think is-- I've seen consulting
organizations

trying to build product
for their customers. What is challenging in
that case is that typically

what you have is your building
product for one customer. And that's more like
developing a product that's

tailor-made for one
customer versus building product for an entire market. So that is actually kind
of a different situation.

Because if you're not
serving an entire market but one specific customer, that
is kind of a different one.
MODERATOR: Thanks. OK, next question from Flavia.

Is there, if any, a best moment
to look for external funding?

LAURA MARINO: Donna, I'll let
you start because [INAUDIBLE]. DONNA NOVITSKY: I missed it. Is there a best moment
What did you say, Liz?

MODERATOR: Yeah. Is there a best moment to
look for external funding? DONNA NOVITSKY: Well, yeah,
I actually first recommend,

if you can bootstrap it and get
it going as far as possible, the more momentum you have,
the higher your leverage

in raising money. So I would advise you to get
as far as you can bootstrapping

before you would go out to
raise cash because that's what's going to allow you
to keep the biggest

share of the company
for yourself. You will be dealing from
a position of power. What I like to
think of in general

is that cash is a commodity. Successful entrepreneurs
are not commodities.

That is your superpower. The fact that you've already
got your business off the ground

is going to give you a lot
more leverage in raising funds. LAURA MARINO: And
what I would add,

because I've been in companies
kind of going through the-- getting funding for B
and C rounds and so on.

If you start taking VC
funding, it's great. But the expectations
are very high.

And if you remember, I was
saying that 60% of companies fail in between
exiting the early stage

and going through the scale-up. Partly, it's
because they are not able to grow as fast as
they need for securing

the next round of funding. So the expectations
when you have investors

is that you and your
company are really going to grow fast and
build a big business.

And when you are not
showing those results and you need to go for funding
again, it will be hard.

So I agree that if you can
postpone the funding until you already have some traction,
you're showing some growth

and so on, you are going
to be in much better shape than if you go for
funding very early on.

You get some nice VC funding. But then the pressure is
going to be really immense. DONNA NOVITSKY: I
have one more thing

to add because Laura
reminded me of something. Thanks, Laura. As you're thinking
about raising funds,

you need to equally
be thinking about, what exactly are we going
to get done with this money?

And you are basically making a
commitment to your investors, these are the things
we're going to do. So for instance, you're raising
series A. We're going to go out.

And we're going to get
x number of customers and bring in y
amount of revenue.

And then you focus on
accomplishing that objective. And when you raise the
next round of money,

you say, OK, what is
it we're going to get with this batch of money? We are going to grow to a
bigger market, for instance.

And we're to get this
many more customers. Or we're going to move to an
additional country or things

like that. You need to know exactly
what it is you're going to do with the money. You need to commit
that to your investors.

And you need to deliver on that. And that's what's going to
make your fundraising process
the smoothest possible.  MODERATOR: Thanks so much.
